facts.text: Appeal by special leave in Civil Appeal No. 108 of 1964 against the Award dated May 11, 1962, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, Patna in Reference No. 4 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 108 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated May 11, 1962, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, Patna in Reference No. 4 of 1961.

facts.text: 119 workmen of the respondent employed as cane carrier mazdoors or cane carrier supervisors or jamadars were discharged.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar. It relates to the discharge of 119 workmen of the respondent who were employed as cane carrier mazdoors or as cane carrier supervisors or jamadars.

facts.text: The workmen were seasonal workmen in the respondent's sugar factory.

anchor.surface_text: All these were seasonal workmen. It is necessary to set out in some detail the circumstances leading to the discharge. The respondent is a sugar factory and the crushing season starts usually in the first half of November each year.

facts.text: Crushing season starts usually in the first half of November each year, concerned with November and December 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a sugar factory and the crushing season starts usually in the first half of November each year. We are companycerned in the present appeal with November and December 1960.

facts.text: Respondent introduced incentive bonus scheme from season 1956-57, continued with changes.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that from the season 1956-57, the respondent introduced an incentive bonus scheme in the factory. The scheme companytinued thereafter from season to season with certain changes.

facts.text: For 1960-61 season starting November 1960, respondent proposed incentive bonus scheme with changes unacceptable to workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears that in the beginning of each season, the respondent used to put forward the incentive bonus scheme and companysult the workmen. The same thing was done when the season 1960-61 was about to start in November 1960.

facts.text: General secretary of the union suggested alterations to the scheme on November 7, 1960, including norm of 125,000 maunds per day crushing.

anchor.surface_text: But the scheme for this season proposed by the respondent companytained certain changes which were apparently number acceptable to the workmen. One of the features in the scheme was that the crushing of sugar cane per day should be 32,000 maunds.

facts.text: No agreement reached on incentive bonus scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The general secretary of the union of the workmen suggested certain alterations for the companysideration of the respondent on November 7, 1960, and one of the main alterations suggested was that the numberm for per days crushing should be 125,000 maunds of cane and thereafter incentive bonus should be given at a certain rate.

facts.text: Respondent complained that union secretary incited workmen to go slow due to change in scheme, mild go-slow in cane carrier department from November 10, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: No agreement seems to have reached on the incentive bonus scheme, and the companyplaint of the respondent was that the secretary incited the workmen to go slow in companysequence of the change in the scheme. Consequently mild go-slow in cane the carrier department which is the basic department in a sugar mill began from the very start of the season on November 10, 1960.

facts.text: On November 27, 1960, workmen in cane carrier department started deliberate go-slow in combination, reducing average daily crushing to 26,000 maunds.

anchor.surface_text: The L P N 4SCI respondents case further was that on November 27, 1960, the workmen in the cane carrier department started in companybination with one another to go-slow deliberately and wilfully and in a planned manner and thus reduced the average daily crushing to 26,000 maunds cane which was much less than the average crushing in previous seasons.

facts.text: Respondent issued general notice on December 15, 1960, alleging go-slow since November 27, 1960, demanding undertaking for minimum 32,000 maunds daily crush or face discharge.

anchor.surface_text: When the position became serious the respondent issued a general numberice on December 15, 1960 inviting the attention of the workmen companycerned to this state of affairs which had been companytinuing of any rate since November 27, 1960. This numberice was in the following terms-- At the instigation of Shri J. Krishna, the General Secretary of your Union...

facts.text: Notice of December 15, 1960 was put on notice-board with translations and sent individually to workmen in cane carrier department.

anchor.surface_text: This numberice was put on the numberice-board along with translations in Hindi and Urdu and it was also sent individually to the workmen in cane carrier department.

facts.text: Union secretary replied to notice on December 15, 1960, denying go-slow and allegations.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy was also sent to the Secretary of the union with the workmen companycerned to submit their willingness as desired by the respondent in the numberice in question either individually or even companylectively through the union. The secretary of the union replied to this numberice on the same day and said that it was full of maliciously false and mischievous statements.

facts.text: Three workmen gave undertakings as required, the rest did not.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case was that three workmen gave undertakings as required in the numberice while the rest did number.

facts.text: Respondent issued notice at 5 p.m. on December 17, 1960 discharging 119 workmen who failed to give undertaking, effective December 18, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence of this attitude of the workmen, the respondent issued a numberice at 5 p.m. on December 17, 1960 which was in the following terms The following workers of the cane carrier station who failed to record their willingness in factory managers office by 4 p.m. this day the 17th December, 1960...

facts.text: General strike by union from December 17, 1960 to December 22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the services of the workmen companycerned stood discharged from December 18, 1960 under this numberice. This was followed by a general strike in pursuance of the numberice served on the respondent by the union on December 17, 1960. The strike companytinued upto December 22, 1960...

facts.text: Joint application by both parties to Government on December 21, 1960 for reference.

anchor.surface_text: when as a result of an agreement it was decided that the case of the discharged workmen and the question of wages for the strike period be referred to adjudication. Consequently a joint application by both parties was made to Government on December 21, 1960.

facts.text: Government referred two questions to tribunal on January 25, 1961: (1) Whether discharge of workmen justified? (2) Wages for strike period Dec 18-22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Government then made a reference of the following two questions to the tribunal on January 25, 1961-- Whether the discharge of workmen mentioned in the Appendix was justified. If number, whether they should be re-instated and or they are entitled to any other relief? Whether the workmen be paid wages for the period 16-00 hrs. on December 18, 1960 to 8-00 hours on December 22, 1960?

facts.text: No domestic enquiry held by respondent before discharge as per Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the respondent had held numberenquiry as required by the standing Orders before dispensing with the services of the workmen companycerned.

facts.text: Tribunal considered evidence and concluded there was go-slow between November 27 and December 15, 1960, discharge justified.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when the matter went before the tribunal, the question that was tried was whether there was go-slow between November 27, 1960 and December. 15, 1960. ... After companysidering all the evidence it came to the companyclusion that there was go slow during this period. Consequently it held that the discharge of the workmen was fully justified.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave, appeal concerned only first reference question.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellants came to this Court and obtained special leave and that is how the matter has companye up before us. We are companycerned in the present appeal only with the first question which was referred to the tribunal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held tribunal entitled to investigate go-slow as real reason for discharge, reading notices of Dec 15 and 17 together.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is numberforce in this argument. ... We are of opinion that the two numberices of December 15 and December 17 have to be read together and it may be pointed out that the numberice of December 17th does refer to the earlier numberice of December 15th.

facts.text: Supreme Court held respondent could justify discharge before tribunal despite no enquiry, as per precedents.

anchor.surface_text: It is number well-settled by a number of decisions of this Court that where an employer has failed to make an enquiry before dismissing or discharging a workman it is open to him to justify the action before the tribunal by leading all relevant evidence before it...

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld tribunal's finding of go-slow from Nov 27 to Dec 15, 1960 based on crushing speed evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether there was go-slow during the period from November 27 to December 15, 1960 is a question of fact and the tribunal has companye to the companyclusion that there was go-slow during this period.

facts.text: Average crushing speed Nov 27-Dec 15, 1960 was 27,830 maunds per day, drop from previous.

anchor.surface_text: That chart shows a crushing speed of 29,859 maunds per day from November 10 to 26, when, according to the respondent, there was only mild go-slow. We are however companycerned with the period from November 27 to December 15, 1960 and the crushing speed for 24 hours during that period was 27,830.

issues.text: Whether the tribunal misdirected itself as to the scope of the reference such that it was concerned only with deciding if the discharge for not giving an undertaking was justified, and not whether there was go-slow justifying discharge?

anchor.surface_text: In the first place it is contended that the tribunal misdirected itself as to the Scope of the reference and that all that the tribunal was concerned with was to decide whether the discharge of the workmen for not giving an undertaking was justified or not, and that it was not part of the duty of the tribunal to decide whether there was go-slow between the relevant dates which would justify the order of discharge.

issues.text: Whether, absent charge-sheets and enquiry as required by Standing Orders, the respondent could justify the discharge before the tribunal which had jurisdiction to go into merits of go-slow?

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it is urged that the respondent had given no charge-sheets to the workmen concerned and had held no enquiry as required by the Standing Orders. Therefore, it was not open to the respondent to justify the discharge before the tribunal, and the tribunal had no jurisdiction to go into the merits of the question relating to go-slow.

issues.text: Whether the tribunal's finding that go-slow was proved is perverse, ignoring relevant evidence?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it is urged that the finding of the tribunal that go-slow had been proved was perverse and the tribunal had ignored relevant evidence in coming to that conclusion.

issues.text: Whether the discharge of workmen mentioned in the Appendix was justified? If not, to what relief entitled?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the discharge of workmen mentioned in the Appendix was justified. If not, whether they should be re-instated and or they are entitled to any other relief?

issues.text: Whether workmen entitled to wages for strike period from 16:00 hrs December 18 to 08:00 hrs December 22, 1960?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the workmen be paid wages for the period 16-00 hrs. on December 18, 1960 to 8-00 hours on December 22, 1960?

arguments.claim: The tribunal misdirected itself as to the scope of the reference; it was only concerned with whether discharge for not giving an undertaking was justified, not whether there was go-slow justifying discharge

anchor.surface_text: In the first place it is contended that the tribunal misdirected itself as to the Scope of the reference and that all that the tribunal was concerned with was to decide whether the discharge of the workmen for not giving an undertaking was justified or not, and that it was not part of the duty of the tribunal to decide whether there was go-slow between the relevant dates which would justify the order of discharge.

anchor.surface_text: We have already set out the relevant term of reference and it will be seen that it is wide and general in terms and asks the tribunal to decide whether the discharge of the workmen concerned was justified or not.

We are however concerned with the period from November 27 to December 15, 1960 and the crushing speed for 24 hours during that period was 27,830.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether there was go-slow during the period from November 27 to December 15, 1960 is a question of fact and the tribunal has come to the conclusion that there was go-slow during this period.

arguments.claim: Tribunal correctly found go-slow Nov 27-Dec 15 based on evidence

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when the matter went before the tribunal, the question that was tried was whether there was go-slow between November 27, 1960 and December. 15, 1960. ... After considering all the evidence it came to the conclusion that there was go slow during this period. Consequently it held that the discharge of the workmen was fully justified.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not perverse; SC reviewed evidence and upheld

holdings.text: The tribunal was entitled to investigate whether there was go-slow tactics justifying the discharge as the reference was in wide and general terms asking whether the discharge was justified.

anchor.surface_text: We have already set out the relevant term of reference and it will be seen that it is wide and general in terms and asks the tribunal to decide whether the discharge of the workmen concerned was justified or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide general reference does not limit to formal reason in notice; parties led evidence on go-slow; joint application not confined to undertaking refusal.

holdings.text: The two notices of December 15 and December 17 have to be read together; the real reason for discharge was go-slow, not mere failure to give undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the two notices of December 15 and December 17 have to be read together and it may be pointed out that the notice of December 17th does refer to the earlier notice of December 15th.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dec 17 notice refers to Dec 15; Dec 15 details go-slow charge and offers overlook if undertaking given; substance shows go-slow as basis.

holdings.text: The first part of the notice of December 15, 1960 which was served on each individual workman was certainly a charge by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree that there was no charge by the respondent against the workmen concerned. The first part of the notice of December 15, 1960 which was served on each individual workmen was certainly a charge

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice details misconduct facts; served individually; workmen knew charge despite no formal heading.

holdings.text: Where an employer has failed to make an enquiry before dismissing or discharging a workman it is open to him to justify the action before the tribunal by leading all relevant evidence before it.

anchor.surface_text: It is now well-settled by a number of decisions of this Court that where an employer has failed to make an enquiry before dismissing or discharging a workman it is open to him to justify the action before the tribunal by leading all relevant evidence before it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from multiple SC cases (Indian Iron Steel, Sasamusa Sugar, Phulbari Tea, etc.); applies to s.10 reference as s.33; avoids delay/injustice.

holdings.text: A defective enquiry stands on the same footing as no enquiry and in either case the tribunal would have jurisdiction to go into the facts.

anchor.surface_text: A defective enquiry in our opinion stands on the same footing as no enquiry and in either case the tribunal would have jurisdiction to go into the facts and the employer would have to satisfy the tribunal that on facts the order of dismissal or discharge was proper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with prior rulings; tribunal decides merits de novo.

holdings.text: The finding of the tribunal that there was go-slow during November 27 to December 15, 1960 is not perverse and is justified on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether there was go-slow during the period from November 27 to December 15, 1960 is a question of fact and the tribunal has come to the conclusion that there was go-slow during this period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not based on no evidence; crushing speed drop to 27,830 maunds/day from normal ~32,000; past history; charts W-4, W-7; admission of withdrawing extra efforts.

holdings.text: Provision in s.64(2)(d) Factories Act being special overrides ss.55(1),(2); Bihar rules exempt sugar factories from rest intervals for cane crushing.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this provision in s. 64 2 d being a special provision will over-ride both sub-ss. 1 and 2 of s. 55, for it gives power to the State Government by making rules to exempt certain types of factories from the application of the whole of s. 55

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special exemption power overrides general rest provisions; 1950 Bihar rules exempt cane crushing subject to refreshment condition.

holdings.text: The discharge of the workmen was fully justified.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Go-slow proved as misconduct; justified despite no prior enquiry; sufficient opportunity overlooked.

precedents.citation: Indian Iron Steel Co. v. Their workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: see Indian Iron Steel Co. v. Their workmen 1 but also to satisfy itself on the facts adduced before it by the employer whether the dismissal or discharge was justified, We may in this connection refer to M s Sasa Musa Sugar Works P Limited v. Shobrati Khan 2 , Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen 3 and the Punjab National Bank Limited v. Its Workman 4 There three cases were further considered by this Court in Bharat Sugar Mills Limited. v. Shri Jai Singh 5

precedents.case_name: Indian Iron & Steel Co. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Where employer fails to hold domestic enquiry before dismissing or discharging workman, tribunal can go into merits and employer can lead evidence to justify the action

precedents.citation: M s Sasa Musa Sugar Works P Limited v. Shobrati Khan 2

anchor.surface_text: We may in this connection refer to M s Sasa Musa Sugar Works P Limited v. Shobrati Khan 2 , Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen 3 and the Punjab National Bank Limited v. Its Workman 4 There three cases were further considered by this Court in Bharat Sugar Mills Limited. v. Shri Jai Singh 5 , and reference was also made to the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Shri Ram Swarath Sinha v. Belaund Sugar Co. 6 It was pointed out that the main effect of omission to hold an enquiry was merely this that the tribunal would not have to consider only whether there was a prima facie case but would decide for itself on the evidence adduced whether the charges have really been made out.

precedents.case_name: M/s Sasa Musa Sugar Works (P) Limited v. Shobrati Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: Where employer fails to hold domestic enquiry before dismissing or discharging workman, tribunal can go into merits and employer can lead evidence to justify the action

precedents.citation: Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen 3

anchor.surface_text: Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen 3 and the Punjab National Bank Limited v. Its Workman 4 There three cases were further considered by this Court in Bharat Sugar Mills Limited. v. Shri Jai Singh 5 , and reference was also made to the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Shri Ram Swarath Sinha v. Belaund Sugar Co. 6 It was pointed out that the main effect of omission to hold an enquiry was merely this that the tribunal would not have to consider only whether there was a prima facie case but would decide for itself on the evidence adduced whether the charges have really been made out. It is true that three of these cases, except Phulbari Tea Estates case 3 , were on applications under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

precedents.case_name: Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Where employer fails to hold domestic enquiry before dismissing or discharging workman, tribunal can go into merits and employer can lead evidence to justify the action

precedents.citation: the Punjab National Bank Limited v. Its Workman 4

anchor.surface_text: and the Punjab National Bank Limited v. Its Workman 4 There three cases were further considered by this Court in Bharat Sugar Mills Limited. v. Shri Jai Singh 5 , and reference was also made to the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Shri Ram Swarath Sinha v. Belaund Sugar Co. 6 It was pointed out that the main effect of omission to hold an enquiry was merely this that the tribunal would not have to consider only whether there was a prima facie case but would decide for itself on the evidence adduced whether the charges have really been made out. It is true that three of these cases, except Phulbari Tea Estates case 3 , were on applications under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. But in principle we see no difference whether the matter comes before the tribunal for approval under s. 33 or on a reference under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

precedents.case_name: Punjab National Bank Limited v. Its Workman
precedents.cited_proposition: Where employer fails to hold domestic enquiry before dismissing or discharging workman, tribunal can go into merits and employer can lead evidence to justify the action

precedents.citation: Bharat Sugar Mills Limited. v. Shri Jai Singh 5

anchor.surface_text: There three cases were further considered by this Court in Bharat Sugar Mills Limited. v. Shri Jai Singh 5 , and reference was also made to the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Shri Ram Swarath Sinha v. Belaund Sugar Co. 6 It was pointed out that the main effect of omission to hold an enquiry was merely this that the tribunal would not have to consider only whether there was a prima facie case but would decide for itself on the evidence adduced whether the charges have really been made out. It is true that three of these cases, except Phulbari Tea Estates case 3 , were on applications under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

precedents.case_name: Bharat Sugar Mills Limited v. Shri Jai Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Where employer fails to hold domestic enquiry before dismissing or discharging workman, tribunal can go into merits and employer can lead evidence to justify the action

precedents.citation: Shri Ram Swarath Sinha v. Belaund Sugar Co. 6

anchor.surface_text: and reference was also made to the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Shri Ram Swarath Sinha v. Belaund Sugar Co. 6 It was pointed out that the main effect of omission to hold an enquiry was merely this that the tribunal would not have to consider only whether there was a prima facie case but would decide for itself on the evidence adduced whether the charges have really been made out. It is true that three of these cases, except Phulbari Tea Estates case 3 , were on applications under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. But in principle we see no difference whether the matter comes before the tribunal for approval under s. 33 or on a reference under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. In either case if the enquiry is defective or if no enquiry has been held as required by Standing Orders, the entire case would be open before the tribunal and the employer would have to justify on facts as well that its order of dismissal or discharge was proper.

precedents.case_name: Shri Ram Swarath Sinha v. Belaund Sugar Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Where employer fails to hold domestic enquiry before dismissing or discharging workman, tribunal can go into merits and employer can lead evidence to justify the action

anchor.surface_text: It appears that till this court condemned the practice of go-slow in the case of Bharat Sugar Mills 1 . It was not unusual in the State of Bihar for workmen to give notice of go-slow to employers as if it was a legitimate weapon to be used in matters of dispute between the employers and the workmen. In the present case the respondent had complained as far back at 1950 that go-slow was being resorted to. In 1950 a court of enquiry was constituted to enquire into this question and it made a report that there was a slow-down on the part of the workman for several days in February-March 1950.

precedents.case_name: Bharat Sugar Mills Limited v. Shri Jai Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Supreme Court condemned the practice of go-slow

outcome.relief_summary: The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed, upholding the Industrial Tribunal's award that the discharge of the 119 workmen was fully justified due to go-slow tactics.

anchor.surface_text: It is now well-settled by a number of decisions of this Court that where an employer has failed to make an enquiry before dismissing or discharging a workman it is open to him to justify the action before the tribunal by leading all relevant evidence before it
In this view of the matter, the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: A defective enquiry in our opinion stands on the same footing as no enquiry and in either case the tribunal would have jurisdiction to go into the facts and the employer would have to satisfy the tribunal that on facts the order of dismissal or discharge was proper.
In this view of the matter, the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed.

Precedent p1 states the rule allowing justification before tribunal without domestic enquiry, directly supporting holding h4 which articulates the same principle.
Precedent p2 mirrors the text of h4 on employer justifying dismissal without enquiry before tribunal.

Precedent p5 reinforces h4 regarding tribunal's role in justifying discharge sans domestic enquiry.
